title: [Personal Opinion] Unjustified Chat Restrictions
body:
So early today I played a game with my cousin as a duo bot lane, had a really rude and out of line team mate that flamed the team and kept asking for team mates to be reported for trolling; all the while he was sitting on the pad afk saying he was done playing. Game ended, we lost, no big deal, move on. That's what I thought, till I got slapped with a 25 game chat restriction. 

I'm not here to rant and rave about how terrible the system is and claim innocence in the whole en devour, but I will claim that what was considered unsportsmanlike behavior in a, team game, is completely shocking. Attached below is screen shots of my chat log from the client, a replay of the game, and copied text from said chat log. There was only one game in the card that was sent to me showing why I was restricted from chat.

Once again, this is mainly for a discussion of whether or not the rules have gotten too strict for both an online game and a team game. (I left the Player support specialist name out as to keep their privacy, while also blocking out the champs name so no one can look back and see said person playing via match history) 

> https://matchhistory.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/#match-details/NA1/3258616405/227670709?tab=overview

Catwalk Lady: *face palm*

I assume you don't know, but riots ban bot for chat is automated, and uses keywords to chat restrict you. You say enough of these keywords, you earn more and more points, if the points reach a certain threshhold, the bot bans.

Keywords I noticed: ff, leaving, trolling, toxic, salt, afk. 

The bot doesn't take context, it takes what words you say at flat value, If you spell it weird or say vague things that people will normally not use, the bot will not detect it.

Riot's bot has been banning a lot of people falsely lately, and they're not doing anything about it. I suggest finding a new game, Riot doesn't really care about the players supporting their games atm.

Untrue. Period.

It is not "keywords" based at all. Stop spreading misinformation on the boards.

There have not been a lot of "false" bans recently, either.

Still not finding the exact commentary, BUT IT IS A DICTIONARY BASED-PROGRAM. You stop the misinformation.

"100 million Tribunal votes later, we turned machine learning loose on the dataset to see if we could classify words and phrases in 15 different languages from negative to positive. Just classifying words was easy, but what about more advanced linguistics such as whether something was sarcastic or passive-aggressive? What about more positive concepts, like phrases that supported conflict resolution?"

This is only a clip of the commentary I'm seeking. It DOES target keywords, but it IS more than just a word filter.

While I'm struggling to retrace my steps, how about you back your own words up with the commentary by the designers themselves (not some Riot representative) that it is not based on keywords *at all*?

(edit) Riot Tantram:
"The IFS uses machine learning. It does not simply look for the presence of words or phrases. It is able to evaluate your history..."
If the system did not use keywords, he would have said 'It does not look for the presence of words or phrases.' Adding the word "simply" means that it does not *only* do so.

I will continue to show you, because this is not conclusive enough. If you are looking, try searching between 12/1/2013 and 1/1/2015. The automated system was implemented early 2014.

(another edit) Begin wall of text. There is information that the common user has no use for. The excuse for this is that such common users should not be aware of the specifics of the system, as it is subject to certain agendas. Namely, the ability to skew results. I believe this is enough of a word-padding to discourage most casual readers to stop. Begin actual content: Perhaps part of the issue is that "dictionary based program" has no solid meaning. As I'm understanding it based on the developer's commentary, the program identifies words and phrases and assigns them values- both positive and negative- and evaluates the entire string of the user's logs and gives it an overall value. Highly negative values result in rapid punishment. It does not care about context. These values are constantly updated- the machine learning part in play- by evaluating the frequency of reports and correlating words and phrases used in those reports. It also adds words and phrases- both positive and negative- on the same premise. It counts honors as positive reports. So, if paired with a lot of positive values, the chat log is evaluated less harshly- though not to a degree that they can escape their toxicity. It does, however, still give credit to positive chat. Hence why it can be misused by common miscreants... but it doesn't seem to be common knowledge yet. This feature was implemented to help prevent false positives, which was a major concern at the inception of the program. All this is to help establish an understanding of what is meant by 'dictionary based program'. It does not actively translate the words in a way that the program can understand it, it merely assigns values which, in turn, contribute to an overall score.

This is rather mildly negative. Honestly, this is showing a new low bar (in the positive regard) for what constitutes punishable chat. My suspicion is that the automated system is tagging this as punishable because people are simply frequently reporting people with chat logs similar to this. 

Is it accurate? I think it's wrong. Will they reverse the bot's judgement? NOPE.

The only merit here, I think, is that you've had prior violations and the sensitivity has shot up. I'd hate to be in your position. Your wording was... relatively polite. I'd advise outright turning off chat or refuse to respond or speak about toxic players at all. I'll be personally adding that to my list: pretend the toxic person doesn't exist.

Or I might quit playing, because I think its objectionable to hold my tongue and trust in a system that only somewhat stops toxicity. As an American I expect to be allowed to defend myself if I feel needlessly attacked, physically or otherwise.

Reasonable. However, this doesn't apply in this case. There's nothing to defend yourself from in any sense when we're talking about League or any online video game. Not unless you've provided an abundance of information about yourself such as your location and name that would allow someone to actually be able to find and harm you. 
 
> I believe we must value our ego as well, and defend it at times. To do so otherwise is to invite injury to the ego. Some can do this effortlessly with willful ignorance of others opinions, others with great kindness and tolerance, others do so with a sort of arrogant armor. There are many ways, but each have their weaknesses and you must defend yourself.

I actually think that encouraging negative responses to a bruised ego is rather primitive and uncivilized. I can tell you from first hand experience that such a community will be utterly barbaric and many times, uncomfortable to live around.

On one hand, you're saying there's nothing to defend against, and then on the other, you're calling the response to it to be utterly barbaric. With such extremes to the single issue, it suggests that something in the middle exists. If you can ignore scathing, volatile comments, you can tolerate a tempered defense.

I am certain that if Riot's rules were applied to real life, you have a situation similar to Dolores Jane Umbridge (Harry Potter). Such suppression dampens the human spirit. In more practical terms, as humans, we're inclined to use anger to overcome problems. Channeled with intelligence and temperament, we are positively rewarded in practical terms (using the anger to focus on the issue and utilize problem solving inclinations) in fixing them and in terms of personal satisfaction (having been able to overcome a source of frustration).

Trolls, careless/idiotic performance, poor teamwork/communication, hostile taunting, being victim of "cheap shots", and much more- all contribute to anger. Expressing anger is generally useless, but defending oneself with that anger in a proper manner (it does not matter what emotions you use if you communicate properly) is a tool to establish confidence in competence in others and as a motivational build up for the defender. It also emphasies error in others- and recognizing one's errors IS an important thing.

The stoic perspective (which is the dominant perspective on this board) abhors anger. It is the vice of self control, viewed as destructive. The truth, this is only the result of rage. Anger in itself is not ugly. Anger propels ambition and achievements, rewarding those who use it. What is ugly is rage- the uncontrolled expression of anger. Rage generally occurs when anger is allowed to build up without release- and without resolution. Hence why Dolores Jane Umbridge is such a bad character. She suppresses the gainful use of anger as though it were a good thing. I wish I could speak on the social opinions on it- such as from various religions- but suffice to say that some recognize anger as evil, others as good, and some indifferently. Generally, the world looks down on it, but science is showing that it can be POWERFULLY positive.

Anger does not control people. These fools who make the excuse "I was just so angry" are really saying "I didn't think about the consequences of what came to mind at the time." You don't have to be negative when you're mad. Rather, defending oneself is actually a positive engagement- "I am capable. I made a mistake, nothing more." "That was an excellent attack. Don't expect that to work against me a second time." "I did not expect that. How should I/we deal with it?"

Don't take it to heart. Honestly, while the PB board members are diligent in their own rights and they all have their pro's and cons individually or as a group. They mostly downvote everything! --------------------------------------------------

That said, talking about the topic at hand. Riot's punishment policy has become so difficult to implement with a 'human' flavor because, in my opinion, their work never reduces. Whether they can or cannot. Accounts are banned but the players behind those accounts are never banned for a fixed period of time. These players aren't asked to stop playing the game for some time and told to chill; to control their toxic levels. I don't know if this is because they want them to keep playing the game. Or because they aren't able to id ban someone! Whatever the reason is, it causes the report load to never **decrease**. So you ban an account and the player has 9 alternate ones or simply makes a new one! And you're back to square one. Because he's harassing someone again, you're getting the same number of reports **again**. 

And this why the way that they handle things feel so unfair at times. Its not consistent either! Bots are used to scan reports. I don't know how this AI bot is evolving. Whether it is actually learning, how its learning. What is the degree of learning, to what point it will be able to judge reports once its reached its zenith? Whether it will be able to judge context and make an assessment of a report with human degree of comprehension? But at the moment, its mostly just something that racks up reports. And blots out players who use ZT words, _regardless of context_. Like, some guy calling an actual feeder running down mid - Troll. Gets a smack on the back of his hand with a 10-game CR, just like the guy running down mid. That's the state of things right now. 

So, that is why there's a lack of 'human' flavor. And its going to remain so while there is a huge player base which is probably not reducing anytime soon! The best way to keep yourself safe or defend yourself from other people's nonsense is to simply mute everyone and everything. Play the game at your own pace!

Then the one time I argue with someone who was intentionally being, let be real, toxic, I get hit with a smack that isn't anywhere close as to what I find, pleasurable. 

Considering this is a 25-game chat restriction and not a 10-game one it means that you have a trend of this type of behavior and have been punished (probably for this behavior) before, and while it's not severe it's consistent enough to where it added up over time. I say this because the IFS hands out punishments based on consistency x severity.
 
> The reps advice is wonderful but honestly. Muting and ignoring players isn't gonna fix the problem. Cause that player can just report back and the system will find SOME reason to punish. Since at this rate, muting players will most likely be seen as a form as unsportsmanlike conduct. Cause you're ignoring your own team. We're starting to walk from the line of "Oh wells, It's a game and I can do better." to "My feelers were hurt, someone punish them.". 

That's not how it works. Reports only flag a game for review (only one is needed btw), and if nothing of guilt is found then the report is thrown out and deemed false. If it's deemed valid then it consults its backlog of sorts to see if it's a consistent pattern, and if it is then it hands out a punishment, and If it's not then it's stored away for future reference. Bad games happen, which is why outside of extreme circumstances no one is punished for just one or two games.

As for muting and ignoring, while I get the urge not to mute and to just type back, at the end of the day it's not gonna solve anything. If they're tllted then arguing with them will make them play worse, while if they're intentionally acting up then you're just giving them the response they want. By muting/ignoring them and focusing on your own game you don't tilt them further/give them the reaction they want, making it more likely they'll play better.

Sure you could always try saying things like "don't worry, we'll do better next time" or "hey man, chill out", but if the other person isn't receptive then just drop it and move on rather than pester them about it, as nothing you say will get through to them.

Something else you could try doing when you're frustrated is yelling and raging at the screen, punching a pillow/bed/chair armrests/punching bag or squeezing a stress ball or something. Any of these things will let you vent without compromising your teams chances of success.

Also don't forget about things like pings or clicking on cds/jg timers/ults as they can communicate basic things quicker than chat can.
